The speed of matter coming out from the rocket engine should have been mentioned. In theory, there is nothing limiting you use a single electron as fuel and shot the complete rocket out from the gravity well of the Milky Way (or even the local cluster). OK there are some "minor" problems, like you would immediately fall apart due to the acceleration , but still, that 100x rocket size is only true, if you're using chemical engines. Use e.g. ion engine, or atomic engine, and your efficiency "skyrockets"... :) My point is that payload/mass ratio can be much better, we simply don't know how to realize it.
(P.s. I know, the single electron would have a significant mass/energy, which is mass, decreasing the total mass of the rocket, so there is still some limit.)

There's no evidence that humans are meant to survive long term away from the earth. We have such limited data on this. Even the ISS folks get regular resources shuttled up from Earth. It takes a vast amount of coordination and effort to keep astronauts alive and sane even when they're just orbiting the earth.

So framing earth as a prison is misguided. It implies we are meant to leave, when maybe that's not even true. Sure, our sun will go nova in a few billion years. Chances of us even being around to see it at nil, at this rate, so there's almost no point in talking about it. Can any human being even comprehend what a billion years looks like? As a species we've only been around for 150,000 or so.

Western science has sold us a dream on technological salvation as the answer to everything. Many ancient scriptures concerning human metaphysics and consciousness practices tell us that humanity has a powerful, innate inner capacity to explore consciousness and the universe by using our spiritual power. What does that mean exactly? I can't say.

But consider that maybe the way out is to go in. Paranormal research is really fascinating these days. We know from many case studies and near death experiences that consciousness can become disentangled from the body and travel on its own.

There is more to the picture than technology. In fact, the more we put our faith into tech, the more we will forget the amazing abilities nature has furnished us with... abilities that are atrophied in the modern urban environment.
We are part of that prison.

All done by pumps, pipes, valves, hoses, a nulzel, a combustion chamber, and a couple of tanks. Buy a firer truck pump, a valve that can handle the pressure, a couple of hoses, maybe a few pipes here, and there, a renforce chamber that can be used for a combation chamber. Also don't forget the nulzel, and a cooling system. The rest is computers, and programming, and the body. Then you have ion engines witch uses plasma, and you can create ion engines with magnets, copper tubing that can create electric arks, and a tank of gas, or basic air. Do it right you get a ion engine. It sounds complicated, but it's not, and anyone can build a basic vergen in they back yard with a couple 100 bucks, or a couple 1,000 of dollars. I received this email recently from the site Ask a Mathematician, Ask a Physicist:

What are "actual pictures" of atoms actually pictures of?.

Physicist:
Actual pictures of atoms aren’t actually pictures at all.
There are a few good rules of thumb in physics. Among the best is:
light acts like you’d expect on scales well above its wavelength and
acts weird on scales below. In order to take a picture of a thing you
need light to bounce …

The only thing physicists have actually seen is basically a computer
image, not the real image, and second, they observe electric fields,
not the particle itself. They do not observe particles themselves;
they are able to observe only the field. However this alone does not
prove anything, but that the electric energy field exists and that’s
about it---no atoms, no photons, no electrons, no quarks. no nothing.
So no, particles do not exist. Particles exist only inside
mathematical abstractions and nothing more and nothing else. We don’t
know what actually exists in the real world, except that there are
energy fields---electric, magnetic and all other forms and all other
kinds of energy fields.

I forgot to add what exactly is visualized with all these microscopes
including STM--the scanning tunneling microscope. What is visualized
is the charge density of the electric field.
Basically you observe vibrations---electric vibrations.
You haven’t seen an atom either. You’ve seen an image you assume to be
an atom, but it is simply an instrument’s representation of the atom.
It is not the atom itself.

These techniques aren’t actually “visual” like microscopes we work
with in biology classes. Microscopes use lenses and light to help zoom
and focus on small objects. Electron microscopes, on the other hand,
use quantum scattering theory to construct the shape of small objects,
then the data is transferred to a computer to create a model. The
wavelengths of visible light ranges on the order of ~370nm to 750nm.
These are all MUCH larger than many particles of interest (and way too
large to view atoms, which are on the order of Angstroms–0.1nm).
Scientists need to be creative to be able to “see” atoms.

So, no, scanning tunneling microscopes and atomic force microscopes
did not prove the existence of atoms.

Below is a piece from the writings of Nichiren who lived during the 13th Century. Long before we knew that there are other solar systems with revolving planets. He knew this and tried to explain it the best he could at the time and age. Like so many other things that he taught which made no sense at the time to so many, but which are now being realised by 21st Century science and technology, he described the world as being a Saha planet (a world of suffering). Occupied by the energies of those who have built up the negative karma in past existences to reward them with a stint on Earth and not somewhere better (or perhaps even worse). He basically explained this world as a place of opportunity for those born here to realise their bad karma (made by past bad causes) and change it by making good causes. He also said that sadly, instead of doing this, many are instead being motivated by their bad karma content to make more bad karma, destroying this world of opportunity in the process. Well.. isn't that the truth, look at what we have done to our world already! He left the key that we can use to tap beyond our negative karma and bring forth our deepest wisdom hidden beneath it to change it... Nam-myoho-renge-kyo

The Four Debts of Gratitude

Background
CONCERNING my present exile,1 there are two important matters that I must mention. One is that I feel immense joy. The reason is that this world is called the sahā world, sahā meaning endurance. This is why the Buddha is also called “One Who Can Endure.” In the sahā world,2 there are one billion Mount Sumerus, one billion suns and moons, and one billion groups of four continents. Among all these worlds, it was in the world at the center—with its Mount Sumeru, sun and moon, and four continents—that the Buddha made his advent. Japan is a tiny island country situated in a remote corner of that world, to the northeast of the country in which the Buddha appeared.

Since all the lands in the ten directions, with the exception of this sahā world, are pure lands, their people, being gentlehearted, neither abuse nor hate the worthies and sages. In contrast, this world is inhabited by people who were rejected from the pure lands in the ten directions. They have committed the ten evil acts or the five cardinal sins, slandered the worthies and sages, and have been unfilial to their fathers and mothers or disrespectful to the monks. For these offenses they fell into the three evil paths, and only after dwelling there for countless kalpas were they reborn in this world. Yet the residue of the evil karma formed in their previous existences has not yet been eradicated, and they still tend to perpetrate the ten evil acts or the five cardinal sins, to revile the worthies and sages, and to be undutiful to their fathers and mothers or irreverent toward the monks.

For these reasons, when the Thus Come One Shakyamuni made his advent in this world, some people offered him food into which they had mixed poison. Others tried to harm him by means of swords and staves, mad elephants, lions, fierce bulls, or savage dogs. Still others charged him with violating women, condemned him as a man of lowly status, or accused him of killing. Again, some, when they encountered him, covered their eyes to avoid seeing him, and others closed their doors and shuttered their windows. Still others reported to the kings and ministers that he held erroneous views and was given to slandering exalted personages. These incidents are described in the Great Collection Sutra, the Nirvana Sutra, and other scriptures. The Buddha was innocent of all such evil deeds. Yet this world is peculiar or deficient in that those with bad karma are born into it and inhabit it in great numbers. Moreover, the devil king of the sixth heaven, scheming to prevent the people of this world from leaving it p.42for the pure lands, seizes every opportunity to carry out his perverse acts.

It appears that his scheming is ultimately intended to prevent the Buddha from expounding the Lotus Sutra. The reason is that the nature of this devil king is to rejoice at those who create the karma of the three evil paths and to grieve at those who form the karma of the three good paths.3 Yet he does not lament so greatly over those who form the karma of the three good paths, but he sorrows indeed at those who aspire to the three vehicles. Again, he may not sorrow so much over those who seek to attain the three vehicles, but he grieves bitterly at those who form the karma to become Buddhas and avails himself of every opportunity to obstruct them. He knows that those who hear even a single sentence or phrase of the Lotus Sutra will attain Buddhahood without fail and, exceedingly distressed by this, contrives various plots and restrains and persecutes believers in an attempt to make them abandon their faith.

Although the age in which the Buddha lived was certainly a defiled one, the five impurities had only just begun to manifest themselves; in addition, the devil stood in awe of the Buddha’s powers. Yet, even in a time when the people’s greed, anger, foolishness, and false views were still not rampant, a group of Brahmans of the Bamboo Staff school killed the Venerable Maudgalyāyana, who was known as the foremost in transcendental powers; and King Ajātashatru, by releasing a mad elephant, threatened the life of the only one in all the threefold world who is worthy of honor.4 Devadatta killed the nun Utpalavarnā, who had attained the state of arhat; and the Venerable Kokālika spread evil rumors about Shāriputra, who was renowned as the foremost in wisdom. How much worse things became in the world as the five impurities steadily increased! And now, in the latter age, hatred and jealousy toward those who believe even slightly in the Lotus Sutra will be all the more terrible. Thus the Lotus Sutra states, “Since hatred and jealousy toward this sutra abound even when the Thus Come One is in the world, how much more will this be so after his passing?”5 When I read this passage for the first time, I did not think that the situation would be as bad as it predicts. Now I am struck by the unfailing accuracy of the Buddha’s words, especially in light of my present circumstances.

I think you've misunderstood the whole "gravity used energy to convince the parts that make up our planet to move together" thing. I mean, it's rather that the parts were existing by themselves at some point in the past, and as they came together energy was released, ultimately in the form of radiation. If energy had been "used" to put the parts together, then the resulting system (the Earth) would possess excess energy. Think of a compressed spring: energy has been expended to compress it and now it contains that energy which can be used, for example, to propel something away from something else. The earth is the opposite of a compressed spring. Energy has not been expended to put the Earth together, but rather energy has been released while it came together. That energy is currently out and about, and in order to separate the parts of the Earth again (i.e. launch stuff into space) we need to provide energy somehow. At this point you're back on track, but the introduction is a bit unfortunate.

Also, what is the "gravity prison at the edge of space"? This makes it sound like (a) space is finite, and (b) the extent of the Earth's gravitational field is finite, none of which is true.

Oh, and final note: You don't really need a lot of kinetic energy to reach a certain altitude as suggested around 4.40. Weather balloons, for example, reach 40 or so kilometers without going particularly fast. Sure, to stay in orbit, that's something else. Anyway, it seems like you're mixing up the concepts of orbital velocity and escape velocity, which are different things.

It's misleading to say we owe a debt of energy to gravity, as if we are the only space entity which does. And indeed we need an organized and controlled way of bringing the payload to low Earth orbit.
It's not so much a debt as a price: a price of both directed and controlled energy, but in the process, also an increase in entropy.

It's useful to launch rockets at an angle to take advantage of a gradual expenditure of fuel that isn't as hard on the vessel. Which makes me wonder why we don't start farming the solar system around us for raw materials, building light ships between low Earth orbit and the moon?

I was watching this and thinking about the Star Trek sci fi technology of the transporter and other related technologies from other works of fiction and it brought up a point. When you transport your mater is decompiled  and sent somewhere else to be remade but if you are changing where you are in a gravitational field for example moving from a ship to a planet you've just lost a load of gravitational potential energy and indeed kinetic energy and momentum if the ship was in orbit. So where does it go? Does it need to be taken into account because what if it is transferred to something else it's not useful to transport down to the planet and then instantly combust due to your energy being transferred as heat or freeze when you go back to your ship and also with momentum if your momentum is taken into account would this change the orbit of the ship in any measurable way because a human in orbit has a lot of momentum so would this affect you negatively if you need to keep a precise orbit. This is not so much an argument about the realism of the technology in the fiction works but rather questioning the chance that such technology is actually possible practically and if it is possible whether we can reach that level of advancement soon(ish)

Actually the stages do NOT need to be self contained. On the Space Shuttle the SRBs were 1 stage, and the orbiter a 3rd. The main tank (the bug orange thing) was the second stage and had no engines, it was just a tank for liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen.
The Space Shuttle is a fantastic way to show the amount of fuel needed to lift cargo into space. The main fuel tank, larger than the shuttle itself was not enough to get the shuttle into orbit. It also needed the solid rocket boosters strapped to the sides.

+kurzgesagt - in a nutshell Hey I have a question for you guys, what would it take to launch a rocket out in space using archimedes laws and the depth of the oceans ? I am wondering if it would be possible (imagining we have the money to build such a structure) to build a giant tube that goes way deep in the ocean, emptying it, placing a spaceship at the bottom of the tube, then refilling it, maintaining the ship at the bottom during the refill and once its empty, release it. Basically build a giant pressure rocket launcher. I imagine the structure of the tube should be massive to resist the pressure, as well as the strucure of the rocket itself, but since it has less fuel to burn, it will also have less mass than nowadays rockets. So if we imagine that the rockets mass will be half the mass of present rockets, at what depth should we put the rocket down the sea in order for it to leave the atmosphere, if its even possible? The way they're putting it, it seems to be the only ways to make spaceflight easier are to find/make more mass-efficient fuel (it provides more thrust for less mass), or to use even lighter, but still strong enough, materials to build the main rocket out of.  I lack reason to believe either of these will happen anytime within this decade (up 'til 12027), but I might be wrong about that.  Also, the reason why too-heavy rockets won't take off is because cubic functions overtake linear functions at a certain point.  (the cubic is mass and the linear is thrust). You know, it's better to call Earth a spherical blanket rather than a gravity well. Calling it a gravity well with a picture like that seems to mean that only people at the top get pulled down, and the people too south get crushed. . .

...

Well that's not exactly how I mean.
Look, Earth is on a net that's like it's a blanket. It's the fabric of space and time. The more mass something has, the bigger the dip it has in the blanket. You can try this for yourself. Put a net on a bowl, and attach it with a rubber band, and put objects on it. The heavier the object is, the more dip it has. If you put a tennis ball on the net, and a pea or something (but it might fall in the net), the pea will just roll down it and come to the tennis ball. In fact, that's just like us. We always fall down the little slope under Earth.

But hang on, this is getting similar to your theory...
Well look. It's hard to picture a 4D wireframe fabric, but that's more like it. The obvious solution is to not have to launch from inside the gravity well. Or at least, not the very bottom of it. Were one to construct a station in geosynchronous orbit, you could (assuming you could produce them) spin thousands of miles of conductive carbon filament down to the surface of the Earth and not only pump uninterrupted solar energy down from orbit but use part of that energy to bring up elevators with materials and cargo, building and launching vessels from space rather than having to shove it up there bits at a time using explosions. The initial cost of the station, the filament, a counterweight station and elevators would be massive, but you could then harvest and distribute gigawatts of energy 24/7 from solar panels in space, unaffected by weather. You could send up people and robots and build larger, more powerful ships that are already in space, never have to take off from a planet and spend all that energy. They could just pick a direction and go.

"Dust particles"

What they aren't telling you is that evolutionary physicists actually believe that Diatomic hydrogen and other gas molecules/atoms can compress in a frictionless environment.

This does not happen, it doesn't matter how massive a nebula is, gas molecules/atoms will never compress sufficiently to the extent of forming atomic bonds, the most dense nebula's have an atmospheric pressure equivalent of 1 quintillion of Earths atmospheric pressure.

Where do you think these dust particles that are not gaseous could have come from hmm?

Stars.

And where did the first proto stars come from?

Diatomic Hydrogen, Helium, Lithium and Beryllium though mainly Hydrogen.

If you cannot compress Diatomic Hydrogen in a frictionless environment because of boyles gas law and gas based physics then how did gas compress sufficiently to form a gravity well sufficient of snowballing diatomic hydrogen and other gas molecules/atoms?

The Earth contains elements that stars cannot even fuse in super nova, the heaviest element a star can fuse is Iron 26, super novas are incapable of forming heavier elements because of the rapid blow off of stellar mass during the rapid implosion sequence.

Just to be clear, gravity doesn't "use energy." Even calling it a "force" is kind of a misnomer, because it suggests that energy is being used to move objects. Really, energy was used to place those objects at a distance from each other, and gravity is just what happens when two masses are at a distance. So the universe didn't use energy to make those trillions and trillions of dust particles come together into the Earth, the universe used energy (in the big bang) to place those dust particles at a distance from each other. The energy "used" to create the Earth was the transfer of the gravitational potential energy of the dust particles into kinetic energy, which smushed the Earth together, and eventually dissipated as heat due to friction. We're on this planet, and while we're on this planet, we have a very low gravitational potential energy relative to an object in space, where we want to be. Whether you choose to look at this difference in potential energy as a "debt" or not is up to you, but it's definitely some kind of energy deficiency.

there is a simple explanation for the rocket science and why its hard to build a good engine

the basic formula for acceleration is:

a = F / m

acceleration is a ratio of force over mass.

now lets consider building the engine. the problem facing most engines is, the more powerful the engine, the heavier it is.

let's look at a = F / m again.

the goal of engines is to increase force as much as possible without increasing the mass too much.

let's say someone is constantly upgrading and making a car engine more "powerful".

the first version puts a force of 1N and weighs 1kg.

the second version is 2N and 2kg.

the third version is 3N and 3kg

this mechanic thinks that the engine becomes stronger as it is upgraded. but in reality, the acceleration is the same.

however, when it comes to cars, truly upgraded engines try to make the engine stronger while not making it too heavy. the ratio of force/mass needs to be high in order to accelerate well.

as for rockets,

in order to go into space more efficiently, we need a strong engine that isn't too heavy. this is a difficult task

Skylon may become a one stage to orbit rocket, its in final development stage in the UK. Kurzgesagt is a cool show, but its too quick to proclaim "impossibilities". Its also highly unlikely, that the only method of propulsion we could ever come up is forever limited to rocketry, especially beyond orbital spaceflight. From space elevators to impulse engines, solar sails, fusion engines to  warp technology, there is plenty of theoretical room to be had. I am not rooting here for blind optimism, far from it, only for a sort of imaginative cautiousness which seems subtly lacking from K. Just recently it may be discovered, that metallic hydrogen is a usable new material which would boost even rocketry`s abilities beyond what could have been imagined before, its pending confirmation, but this is exactly the sort of breakthroughs which can come in the future which renders some assumptions in the video premature.

The main bulkof the series is the existence of an infinite amount of parallel Earth´s *, next to the normal earth, with the main difference of not being occupied by humankind. I don´t want to go deep into the details, I really recommend everyone to read the books, but the point is: One Special Parallel Earth does not exist anymore, because it was destroyed by an Meteor. In consequence, Gravity does not take effect in this gap, too. This error is used by Space-Scientist, who can travel through space without an expensive "escape".

Hey Kurzgesagt, could you make a video on using electromagnetic accelerators (railguns) to get things into orbit? You've talked about rockets, how they really don't work for large payloads and you've talked about space elevators, how they're awesome but the tech doesn't (and may never) exist to create them. I feel like electromagnetic accelerators don't get enough love when it comes to the topic of how to get things into orbit, and sufficient tech already exists. The only problem is that if you wanted to send up sensitive payloads (e.g. Humans) you would need a very long track to get a safe acceleration, meaning it'd be really expensive. Or you could just use it to ship up raw materials, that could survive the extremely high acceleration and make a significantly smaller facility. Just a thought, great video btw.

The faster the craft travels the greater the effect of the Magnus, allowing the craft to save loads of fuel while reaching the Kármán line. Nearly a century after it was theorized, Harvard scientists have succeeded in creating metallic hydrogen. In addition to helping scientists answer fundamental questions about the nature of matter, the material is theorized to have a wide range of applications, ranging from room-temperature superconductors to powerful rocket propellant.
Atomic metallic hydrogen, if metastable at ambient pressure and temperature could be used as the most powerful chemical rocket fuel, as the atoms recombine to form molecular hydrogen. This light-weight high-energy density material would revolutionize rocketry, allowing single-stage rockets to enter orbit and chemically fueled rockets to explore our solar system. To transform solid molecular hydrogen to metallic hydrogen requires extreme high pressures, but has not yet been accomplished in the laboratory. In the proposed new approach electrons will be injected into solid hydrogen with the objective of lowering the critical pressure for transformation. If successful the metastability properties of hydrogen will be studied.

Isn't this kind of wrong though? The video seems to suggest that the universe somehow needs to put energy into a dust cloud for it to form a planet (1:42 "Your atoms were once a part of the dust that the universe expended energy on to get to this place")
I believe though, that the dust cloud really needs to loose energy for it to form a planet. Or rather, the large gravitational potential energy of the cloud gets converted into heat and rotation, as the particles clump together to form the planet. The heat then get's radiated away into the universe over time.
So really we are not bound to earth, because the universe put a lot of energy into us and we need to pay it back. Rather we are stuck here, because we lost a lot of energy to the universe and we need to regain energy, in order to leave the planet.

Maybe it's just semantics or maybe I'm wrong. I'm a big fan anyways. Keep up the good work!

-Are there any plans on how to propell rockets while the "fuel" is staying on earth? Like gun/rail gun/power cort designs?
-If the problem with Mars missions is fuel capacity why not launch the rocket into space and then refuel it with fuel brought from other rockets? Granted there would be a couple of costly delivery missions but it sounds feasible to me, at least if we are willing to spend that money.
-Are there any plans on fuel production in Space? There must be something to burn in Space/on Mars. Even if synthesising is inefficient (e.g. H2) it is probably still more efficient than carrying fuel to space.

Why don't they just build the rocket in space?

The rocket equation states that the difference between your current velocity and your potential velocity is equal to the exhaust velocity, multiplied by the natural logarithm of the ratio between your wet mass and dry mass [with and without fuel respectively]. In order to maximize that difference, known as Delta-V, you have to do a few things:

A. Extract as much momentum from the propellant as possible. To do this, you want the most ideal exhaust gas pressure, which is both why rockets that are designed to be used at sea level have smaller engine bells, and why rockets in space will have much longer and wider engine bells. Look at the Falcon 9 Merlin engines. The bottom stage has room for 9, smaller engines, while the upper stage has one large engine for use in space. Designs for fission rockets also have this trait, but are only meant to be used in space. This is why they all have long engine bells designs that are almost as wide as the test fairings they've been put into

B. Get the ratio of the wet mass to dry mass as high as possible. You want less rocket carrying more fuel, so ideally you want as much fuel in a single tank as possible since the inverse square law tells you that having a tank 10x smaller will carry 100x less fuel, so you would need more tanks to carry more fuel which needs more fuel to lift it which needs more tanks, which would needs more fuel, and you're not getting anywhere with this cycle of nonsense

C. In flight, shed excess weight. For any given stage, carrying dead weight lowers the ratio of wet to dry mass, and you don't want that. This is why asparagus rocket staging is very efficient since it strikes a perfect balance of rocket stability and stage-specific efficiency

D. Increase your exhaust velocity. To do this, you want very hot fuel. Hot fuel is more energetic, and you want to get that energy made into kinetic energy, which is the basis of fission engines. Basically, they pass liquid hydrogen over a fission reactor to keep it cool, which heats up the liquid hydrogen to very high temperatures, where it is then exhausted out the back as hydrogen gas
